key_points: The Rittenhouse verdict has elicited polarized reactions, with right-wing groups and the NRA celebrating, and liberal leaders expressing concerns over vigilantism.
The case touched on divisive issues like gun rights, police brutality, and racial injustice.
Rittenhouse, 18, claimed self-defense after fatally shooting two men and wounding a third during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
Critics see the not-guilty verdict as promoting a 'shoot first, ask questions later' mentality and fear it may invite more political violence.
Supporters, including U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert, view the verdict as a victory for self-defense and the Second Amendment.
There are concerns that the verdict may impact the constitutional right to assemble and lead to an increase in the number and violence of armed protests.
Civil rights activists see the verdict as a symbol of unequal justice and a message that vigilantes are above the law.
Research indicates armed protests are more likely to turn violent, raising fears of more violence at future demonstrations.
Some lawmakers have offered Rittenhouse internships, signaling his status as a symbol to conservatives.
The NRA used the verdict to reaffirm the right to bear arms, while others see the decision as a "great day for America" and individual liberty.
spokespersons: Roudabeh Kishi (Director of Research and Innovation, ACLED)
